title: MD. Monowar Hossain
text:
I am a graduate student at the Institute of Statistical Research and Training (ISRT), University of Dhaka, pursuing an M.S. in Applied Statistics & Data Science. My academic work is driven by a focus on using advanced statistical methodologies to solve real-world problems, particularly within the realms of public health and sociodemographic analysis.
My research interests lie at the intersection of biostatistics and computational data science. I am dedicated to exploring how rigorous inferential models and machine learning techniques can be applied to large-scale datasets to uncover meaningful patterns. At ISRT, I have developed a strong foundation in experimental design, survey sampling, and multivariate analysis, which I aim to apply toward high-impact research in the scientific community.

title: Attending ICASDS 2025: Unlocking New Possibilities in Data Science
text:
I recently had the opportunity to attend the International Conference on Applied Statistics and Data Science (ICASDS 2025), held at the Nabab Nawab Ali Chowdhury Senate Bhaban, University of Dhaka.
The theme of the conference, “Data-driven Solutions: Unlocking New Possibilities,” perfectly aligns with my current academic focus in my M.S. program. Over the course of December 28-29, I engaged with global experts and fellow researchers through a variety of programs:

Key Highlights:

Keynote & Plenary Sessions: Gained insights into the future of global data science trends.
Student Poster Competition: Observed innovative research from peers, which was highly motivating for my own work on geospatial health inequities.
Networking: Connected with statisticians and data scientists during the invited paper sessions.

Attending this conference was a significant milestone in my graduate journey, providing fresh perspectives on how applied statistics can solve complex real-world problems.

title: B.S. Project: Geospatial and Sociodemographic Inequities in NCDs Among Women in Bangladesh
text:
I am pleased to share the completion of my B.S. (Hons.) project in Applied Statistics at the Institute of Statistical Research and Training (ISRT), University of Dhaka.



Institute of Statistical Research and Training (ISRT), University of Dhaka


Supervised by Mr. Priom Saha (Lecturer, ISRT), my research focused on the rising burden of Non-Communicable Diseases (NCDs) among ever-married women in Bangladesh.



Caught a quick moment with Mr. Priom Saha between meetings. Always a pleasure!



Research Overview
Using data from the Bangladesh Demographic and Health Survey (BDHS) 2021–22, I analyzed a nationally representative sample of 5,015 women. The study investigated the prevalence and determinants of hypertension, diabetes, anxiety, and depression.



Acknowledgments
I am deeply grateful to my supervisor, Mr. Priom Saha, for his invaluable guidance, and to my family for their unwavering support. I also dedicate this work to my beloved teachers.

title: Statistics in the Wild: Exploring Experimental Designs at BARI and BRRI
text: On November 7, 2023, as a third-year Applied Statistics student at ISRT, I joined my classmates and faculty members on an educational journey to the heart of agricultural research in Gazipur: BARI and BRRI.

title: Statistics in the Wild: Exploring Experimental Designs at BARI and BRRI
text:
The Journey to BARI



Starting point: Science Library, University of Dhaka.


Our day began early at the University of Dhaka. Traveling to the Bangladesh Agricultural Research Institute (BARI), we were eager to see how the “perfect” designs from our textbooks are implemented in the challenging environment of open-field research.






Arrived at ASIRT, BARI.




The Foundation of Research Our first stop was the ASICT building. During a detailed seminar, we learned about the 622 crop varieties developed by BARI. It was fascinating to hear about the “BARI Mango-4” and the “Anthocyanin Potato,” realizing that statistics is the backbone of these innovations.

title: Statistics in the Wild: Exploring Experimental Designs at BARI and BRRI
text:
Seeing RCBD in Practice
One of the most impactful moments was walking through the brinjal fields (BARI-begun 8). We observed a Randomized Complete Block Design (RCBD) being used to test pest management strategies.



Statistical Rigor in the Field We observed how researchers blocked the area based on soil fertility and sunlight. A key takeaway was learning why predatory mites are ideal for these experiments; since they cannot fly, they remain within their assigned treatment plots, ensuring no “leakage” across the experimental units. This physical constraint validates the independence required for a robust ANOVA.





Visiting the BARI Begun-8 research fields.











BARI Begun-8







Nutrient management of turmeric varieties









BARI Begun-8







Field discussion









Rice variety trials







Field discussion

title: Statistics in the Wild: Exploring Experimental Designs at BARI and BRRI
section: Transitioning to BRRI: The Science of Rice
text:
Transitioning to BRRI: The Science of Rice
After a productive morning at BARI and a quick lunch, we transitioned to the Bangladesh Rice Research Institute (BRRI). As the primary center for rice research in the country, BRRI provided a different perspective on how statistical stability is measured across seasons.



Bangladesh Rice Research Institute (BRRI)





Stability and Adaptability Analysis At BRRI, we focused on the Stability Analysis of Aman rice varieties. The researchers explained that it is not enough for a variety to perform well once; it must show consistent yield across different environments and years. We discussed how they use multi-environment trials (MET) to identify varieties with high adaptability for farmers across Bangladesh.

title: Statistics in the Wild: Exploring Experimental Designs at BARI and BRRI
text:
Sampling Techniques in the Field
One of the most technical discussions occurred while standing among the vast rice plots regarding how data is actually collected from the thousands of plants available.



Systematic Sampling vs. SRS The scientific officers shared a practical secret of field research: they often prefer Systematic Sampling over Simple Random Sampling (SRS) when measuring plant height or panicle length. They explained that in large fields, SRS can inadvertently lead to “clustering” in specific patches that might be unusually healthy or diseased. Systematic sampling ensures an even spread across the entire plot, providing a more reliable estimate of the variety’s true characteristics.





Field discussion

title: Statistics in the Wild: Exploring Experimental Designs at BARI and BRRI
text:
Closing Thoughts: Beyond the Textbook
A Statistician’s Adaptation
By the time we boarded the bus at 5:30 PM, my perspective had shifted. I realized that while our textbooks provide the rigid templates (like the RCBD or Factorial designs), the real skill of an ISRTian lies in adaptation. Whether it is dealing with limited space, soil fertility gradients, or budget constraints, statistics is the tool that allows researchers to find truth amidst real-world chaos.

title: ISRT Students Visit icddr,b Matlab HDSS Site for Hands-on Training
text:
Arrival at the Site



With transportation arranged by the Matlab Health and Demographic Surveillance System (HDSS) under the International Centre for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Bangladesh (icddr,b), we traveled to the central facility of Matlab HDSS, located in a sub-district of Chandpur. We were accompanied by our four faculty members. The date was 29th of April 2025. It was a clear, sunny day as we disembarked from the buses and proceeded to the Internal Training Center (ITC) of Matlab, where we took a short break to freshen up. A breakfast of puri, chhana, and tea was served, after which we gathered in the ITC auditorium for the formal commencement of the visit. Seated comfortably, we were warmly welcomed by Dr. Md Alfazal Khan, Head of icddr,b Matlab HDSS, and Dr. Jamal Uddin Ahmed, Project Research Manager at icddr,b.








Figure 2: Arrival at the Site

title: ISRT Students Visit icddr,b Matlab HDSS Site for Hands-on Training
text:
Opening Presentation



According to Mr. Alfazal, Matlab hospital started as a health center in 1963 and the HDSS was effectively launched in 1966. The specialty of Matlab is its longevity and consistent collection of health and demographic data. Primary donors include the Government of Bangladesh, Canada, Sweden, and the UK. Mr. Alfazal highlighted remarkable feats, such as the cholera vaccine trials. Matlab’s research proved that injectable vaccines were ineffective while oral ones were, leading the WHO to update global recommendations. They also pioneered the Maternal Child Health and Family Planning (MCHFP) model, which the Government of Bangladesh later implemented nationwide to reduce mortality and fertility rates.








Figure 3: Mr. Alfazal presenting






The Matlab Hospital is famous for treating water-borne diseases, treating nearly 60,000 patients yearly. They have published over 8,000 papers since 1963. Current research includes the effectiveness of probiotics for pregnant women and metal-induced neurotoxicity in rural children.

title: ISRT Students Visit icddr,b Matlab HDSS Site for Hands-on Training
text:
Visiting the Field



Following the presentation, we visited a village named Doshpara (village code v059). Data collection in Matlab has been ongoing since 1966 using Galaxy Tabs. Matlab encompasses ~250,000 residents across 142 villages.  Each individual is assigned a unique RID (Respondent ID) which remains unchanged throughout life. Enumerators collect demographic data (birth, death, migration), health data (contraceptives, vaccinations), and GIS data. Our group observed CHRW Jakia Parvin demonstrating how birth and death events are documented live on digital tablets.








Figure 4: Mr. Bashir Uddin explaining

title: ISRT Students Visit icddr,b Matlab HDSS Site for Hands-on Training
text:
Our Presentation
Upon our return to the ITC, a lunch of rice, vegetables, fish, and mutton curry was served. Afterward, our classmates Humayara Mahjebin Turin and Ayesha Siddika Juthi presented an overview of ISRT and our course, AST 406: Research Methodology and Social Statistics.






Humayara Presenting







Ayesha Presenting





We discussed our specific research groups, focusing on topics like gender-based wage inequality, student health, and the impact of living arrangements on academic achievement.

title: ISRT Students Visit icddr,b Matlab HDSS Site for Hands-on Training
text:
The Barge



The ‘Barge’ is a two-storied vessel with a rich history. Originally a British floating jail, it was converted into a floating hospital in 1964. It played a central role in the development of Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT).  Legendary scientists like David Nalin and John Rohde conducted groundbreaking work here. Even after its medical role ended in 1990, it remains a key fixture in the community’s memory, and icddr,b is considering turning it into a museum.








Figure 5: The Barge

title: ISRT Students Visit icddr,b Matlab HDSS Site for Hands-on Training
text:
The Matlab Hospital & Conclusion



The hospital offers specialized diarrheal disease management and maternal health services supported by donors like the Gates Foundation. Witnessing the care provided under challenging conditions was a powerful reminder of the impact of dedicated research.





The Matlab Hospital





As the tour ended, we reflected on the decades of dedication behind icddr,b’s work. Integrating academic knowledge with practical application is a lesson we will carry forward in our research journeys.

title: Appointed as Joint Secretary of DURS Executive Committee 2024-25
text:
I am deeply honored to announce that, as of September 11, 2024, I have been appointed as the Joint Secretary of the Dhaka University Research Society (DURS) for the Executive Committee 2024-25. This appointment represents a significant milestone in my journey with the society, and I am eager to contribute to the continued growth of the research culture at the University of Dhaka.
My involvement with DURS has always been driven by a passion for academic inquiry and a desire to support the student research community. Previously, I had the privilege of serving as the Research Coordinator. In that role, I was responsible for facilitating academic resources and helping students navigate the complexities of research methodology. That experience was fundamental in shaping my understanding of the needs of young researchers and the importance of a well-coordinated support system within the university.
As I transition into the role of Joint Secretary, my responsibilities will expand into the broader administrative and strategic planning of the society. I look forward to working closely with the Executive Committee to streamline our internal communications and coordinate high-impact workshops. Our primary goal for the 2024-25 session is to create an even more inclusive platform where students from all disciplines feel empowered to engage in data-driven and meaningful research.

Reflecting on this transition, I am immensely grateful to the advisory board and my peers for their trust in my capabilities. Moving from a specialized coordination role to an executive leadership position allows me to serve the society with a more comprehensive vision. I am committed to ensuring that DURS remains a pioneer in fostering innovation and academic excellence throughout this upcoming tenure.

title: DURS Executive Committee Meets with Honorable Vice Chancellor
text:
It was a significant honor for the newly formed Executive Committee of the Dhaka University Research Society (DURS) for the 2024-25 session to meet with our honorable Vice Chancellor, Professor Niaz Ahmed Khan, PhD. As the Joint Secretary, I felt privileged to be part of this dialogue where we shared our vision for the upcoming tenure.

Empowering Research Culture During the meeting, the Vice Chancellor expressed his keen interest in the society’s activities and emphasized the importance of fostering a robust research environment within the university. He encouraged us to continue our efforts in bridging the gap between student researchers and global academic standards.
The session concluded with an exchange of ideas on how DURS can better serve the university’s research community. This meeting has provided our team with immense motivation to implement our plans for the 2024-25 session under the guidance and support of the university administration. We are committed to making this year a landmark period for innovation and academic growth at the University of Dhaka.

title: Press Conference: Student Politics Survey Report Publication
text:
On November 17, 2024, the Dhaka University Research Society (DURS) organized a “Meet the Press” event to officially publish our survey report regarding student politics. This report was based on data collected from the student body to understand their perspectives and expectations regarding the political environment on campus.






During the meeting, we presented the key findings and statistical insights from the survey to various national media outlets. This initiative was part of our ongoing effort to use data-driven research to reflect the actual sentiments of the university community.
